body.p: Our company is dedicated to developing software products that are usable for everyone including those with physical challenges and disabilities. Oxygen XML was designed to adhere to the U.S. Government Section 508 accessibility standards:

If you have low vision, the Oxygen Preferences->Fonts page allows you to adjust the font styles and sizes used in the entire application, both for the editing areas and for the UI labels. If you have color blindness you can also adjust most of the colors used in Oxygen either by changing the current color theme from the Preferences->Appearance page or my searching in the Preferences dialog for all color-related settings.

You will receive notification in the console that the access bridge has been enabled.

Once the Java access bridge is enabled, if the JAWS narrator is active, when Oxygen will start up the narrator will start reading content from Oxygen and allow you to interact with the application, read menus, content from opened XML documents and UI components from dialogs and side views.

Here are a few hints for using Oxygen if you are visually impaired:
The top main menu should contain most of the actions that you need to open, save and close documents, switch between opened documents or switch between the various editing modes for already opened XML documents.
The File menu allows you to open, save or close the current edited XML document.
The Edit menu contains actions to undo/redo or cut/copy/paste content. They have the usual shortcuts which can be used instead of directly invoking the actions from the menu.
The Find menu allows you to show the Find/Replace dialog. Sometimes the JAWS narrator overloads the CTRL-F shortcut and presents its own find-replace window but using Oxygen's Find/Replace dialog should allow you to perform complex find/replace operations in the opened file.
In the Options menu you have access to the Preferences dialog containing global application settings and to the Menu Shortcut Keys table which allows you to configure shortcuts for the most used actions.
The Window menu allows you to switch between opened XML documents. Using the Show view submenu you can show a particular side view and give focus to it.
An opened XML document can be edited with accessibility support either in the Text editing mode (in which the XML tags are accessible in the edited content) or in the Author editing mode which hides the XML tags and presents only the text content. You can switch between these editing modes by using the Document->Edit Mode menu.
Editing in the Text editing mode you have access to the entire document XML contents like you have in any text editing application. In addition, using the Window main menu->Show view you can focus on the Attributes, Elements and Outline view. The Attributes view presents the existing and possible attributes which can be inserted in an XML tag. The Elements view shows you the list of XML elements which can be inserted at caret position, pressing F2 on a selected element presents its annotation. The Outline view shows the current path in the XML structure.
The Author view is quite useful for reviewing written XML content because it has support for change tracking and for adding comments. Editing in the Author visual editing mode you have access only to the text content in the XML document. Pressing Shift-F2 will read to you the location in the XML structure. Or you can again use the Outline view for this. In the Author editing mode you can also use the Attributes and Elements views similar to using them in the Text editing mode. Pressing ENTER in the Author visual editing mode can also be used to present the set of allowed elements at the current position.
